levels.name: Shikamaru Nara
levels.description: You are now Shikamaru. He may not be the strongest, but his super-smart brain is his ultimate weapon. With his shadow powers, he can trap anyone who underestimates him. You're now a clever ninja strategist!

levels.name: Temaru
levels.description: Awesome—you've unlocked Temari! With her giant fan, she can whip up slicing wind attacks that knock enemies off their feet. She crushed Tenten with ease and even helped take down one of the Sound Four when Shikamaru was in trouble. A master of long-range battles, Temari is a powerful ally who shows that brains and wind make the perfect combo!

levels.name: Choji Akimichi
levels.description: Nice! You've reached Choji. Don't be fooled—when Choji gets serious, he's unstoppable! He can grow huge and crush his enemies. You've unlocked hidden strength that surprises everyone.

levels.name: Neji Hyuga
levels.description: Awesome! You've become Neji, the Hyuga genius. With your Byakugan, you can see enemy moves before they happen. You're a natural-born prodigy, feared in battle!

levels.name: Rock Lee
levels.description: Hard work pays off—you're now Rock Lee! You can unleash amazing Taijutsu, move faster than the eye can see, and even fight drunk-style if needed. You're proof that training beats talent!

levels.name: Gaara
levels.description: Whoa—you've unlocked Gaara! With sand that obeys your every command, you're one of the scariest Genin ever. Few dare to fight you… and those who do regret it.

levels.name: Sasuke Uchiha
levels.description: Impressive! You're now Sasuke, the Uchiha prodigy. With the Sharingan and the Curse Mark, you're strong enough to rival even Naruto. You've got the power and the cool factor.

levels.name: Naruto Uzumaki
levels.description: Believe it—you've reached Naruto! You can summon giant toads, tap into the Nine-Tails' chakra, and never give up. You're destined for greatness—Hokage level is in sight!

levels.name: Kiba Inuzuka
levels.description: You've unlocked Kiba and his trusty partner Akamaru! With super-sharp senses, lightning-fast reflexes, and a wild fighting style, Kiba fights like a true ninja wolf. Even Naruto had a tough time keeping up with him! Together with Akamaru, his combo attacks can tear through almost any opponent. Fierce, loyal, and fearless—you're now running with the pack!

levels.name: Shikamaru Nara
levels.description: Smart and steady—you're Shikamaru the Chunin now! With your 200 IQ battle plans, you can outthink anyone, even stronger enemies. A true master of strategy!

levels.name: Temari
levels.description: You've leveled up to Temari! With your giant fan, you summon mighty wind blades that can blow enemies away. You're sharp, strong, and always in control of the battlefield!

levels.name: Neji Hyuga
levels.description: You're Neji at Chunin level! Your Byakugan is so powerful that even Jonin are impressed. You see everything and strike with unbeatable precision. A true prodigy at work!

levels.name: Rock Lee
levels.description: You've reached Rock Lee! With Guy-sensei's training and your unstoppable Taijutsu, you fight with the heart of a lion. Open those gates and show your fiery spirit!

levels.name: Sasuke Uchiha
levels.description: Chunin Sasuke unlocked! Faster, stronger, and cooler than ever—you now wield the Sharingan like a pro. Enemies beware: your lightning power is growing!

levels.name: Gaara
levels.description: You're Gaara, the sand master! Even at Chunin exams, no one wanted to face you. With sand that shields and attacks, you're nearly unbeatable. Total boss move!

levels.name: Naruto Uzumaki
levels.description: Believe it—you're Chunin Naruto! You can use the Nine-Tails' chakra and summon giant toads. From underdog to hero, you've become a true force of nature!

levels.name: Pakura
levels.description: Incredible—you've reached Pakura, the blazing hero of the Sand! Feared across the ninja world, she wields the rare Scorch Release, creating fiery orbs that burn hotter than the sun. One touch is enough to defeat an enemy instantly, and with a massive orb, she can scorch entire battlefields. Once hailed as her village's brightest kunoichi, Pakura's power makes her a legend of flame and fury!

levels.name: Neji Hyuga
levels.description: You're Jonin Neji! Your Byakugan is unmatched, and you've become a leader in battle. You're a genius warrior who inspires your entire clan.

levels.name: Might Guy
levels.description: Fired up—you've unlocked Might Guy! With blazing Taijutsu and endless energy, you prove that hard work can rival any genius. Youth power unleashed!

levels.name: Shisui Uchiha
levels.description: Awesome! You've become Shisui, the fastest Uchiha. With your Sharingan and Body Flicker, enemies can't even see you move. You're unstoppable speed!

levels.name: Fugaku Uchiha
levels.description: You've ranked up to Fugaku, leader of the Uchiha! With deadly fire jutsu and unmatched shuriken skills, you're a clan head with burning power.

levels.name: Sakumo Hatake
levels.description: You're Sakumo, the White Fang! With your glowing blade, you strike fear into enemies. Even the strongest ninjas know to respect your lightning-fast skills.

levels.name: Killer B
levels.description: Yo! You've unlocked Killer B, the Eight-Tails' best buddy. With rap, rhymes, and beast power, you're both awesome and unstoppable. Perfect Jinchuriki vibes!

levels.name: Jiraiya
levels.description: Legend unlocked—you're Jiraiya, the Toad Sage! Teacher of legends, master of Rasengan, and total wild card. You're powerful, wise, and hilarious all at once!

levels.name: Kakashi Hatake
levels.description: Congrats, you're Kakashi the Hokage! The Copy Ninja with a thousand jutsu is now the leader of the Leaf. Cool, calm, and legendary.

levels.name: Tsunade Senju
levels.description: You're Tsunade, the Fifth Hokage! With super strength and healing powers, you're the legendary medic who can crush boulders and save lives.

levels.name: Tobirama Senju
levels.description: You're Tobirama, the Second Hokage! Genius inventor and water-style master, you created powerful jutsu that changed the ninja world forever.

levels.name: Minato Namikaze
levels.description: You're Minato, the Yellow Flash! With speed too fast to see and a heart of gold, you're a hero who saved the village with ultimate sacrifice.

levels.name: Hiruzen Sarutobi
levels.description: You're Hiruzen, the Third Hokage! Known as the Professor, you know every jutsu in the village. Wise, kind, and powerful—you're the grand master of Konoha.

levels.name: Hashirama Senju
levels.description: You're Hashirama, the First Hokage! With Wood Style powers and the strength to fight Madara and the Nine-Tails, you're a true legend of Konoha.

levels.name: Naruto Uzumaki
levels.description: Believe it—you've finally become Hokage Naruto! With Sage Mode, Kurama's power, and the will to never give up, you're the strongest Hokage ever!

levels.name: Tobirama Senju
levels.description: You're Legendary Tobirama! Not only a Hokage but also a ninja genius who shaped the future of Konoha. Your wisdom and power make you unforgettable.

levels.name: Kakashi Hatake
levels.description: Legendary Kakashi unlocked! With lightning speed, Sharingan mastery, and endless coolness, you're one of the most powerful ninjas ever.

levels.name: Uchiha Obito
levels.description: You've unlocked the masked legend Obito Uchiha! Once thought lost, he returned as the mysterious Tobi—going from prankster to mastermind of the Akatsuki. With his space-warping Mangekyo Sharingan, Obito can slip through attacks and control battles like no other. Though his heart was broken by tragedy, his power grew so immense that even the strongest shinobi trembled before him. From underdog to unstoppable force, you now wield the might of a ninja who nearly changed the entire world!

levels.name: Uchiha Itachi
levels.description: You've unlocked the legendary Itachi Uchiha! A genius since childhood, he became one of the youngest Anbu captains ever. With his Sharingan and Mangekyo powers, even the strongest shinobi feared him. Though branded a rogue ninja and Akatsuki member, Itachi carried a hidden mission—protecting the Leaf and his little brother at all costs. Calm, mysterious, and unbelievably powerful, you now wield the strength and wisdom of one of the greatest ninjas in history.

levels.name: Minato Namikaze
levels.description: You're Legendary Minato, the Yellow Flash remembered across the world! Even in sacrifice, your speed and bravery live on forever.

levels.name: Sasuke Uchiha
levels.description: Legendary Sasuke! With the Eternal Mangekyo Sharingan and endless power, you're one of the most feared and respected ninjas ever.

levels.name: Naruto Uzumaki
levels.description: Legendary Naruto unlocked! With Sage Mode, Kurama, and thousands of shadow clones, you're the unstoppable hero of the ninja world.

levels.name: Madara Uchiha
levels.description: You've become Madara, the ultimate Uchiha! With the Eternal Mangekyo Sharingan and Perfect Susanoo, you're nearly godlike in power.

levels.name: Kaguya Otsutsuki
levels.description: Final form unlocked—you're Kaguya, the Mother of Chakra! With powers beyond imagination, you're the strongest being in the ninja world. True god-tier!

questions.question: After the storm, the climbers had to turn back due to the **adverse** weather conditions. What does 'adverse' mean in this context?
questions.explanation: In this sentence, 'adverse' describes the negative nature of the weather conditions that forced the climbers to retreat. It means unfavorable or harmful.

questions.question: As a strong **advocate** for animal rights, she frequently speaks at public rallies and lobbies for new legislation. What does 'advocate' mean?
choices: one who recommends or supports a cause
questions.answer: one who recommends or supports a cause
questions.explanation: An 'advocate' is someone who publicly recommends or supports a particular policy or cause, which fits the description of her actions at rallies and for legislation.

questions.question: From the moment they met, they felt a natural **affinity** for each other, sharing many similar interests and a passion for hiking. What does 'affinity' mean?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'affinity' describes the immediate and natural connection between two people, which is a feeling of attraction or liking.

questions.question: The sudden collapse of the government led to a state of **anarchy**, where there were no laws or public order. Fill in the blank with the best choice.
questions.explanation: The context describes a situation where a government's collapse results in a lack of law and order, which is the definition of 'anarchy'.

questions.question: The result was a statistical **anomaly**; it was so different from the other data points that scientists had to re-run the entire experiment. What does 'anomaly' mean?
choices: an irregularity or deviation from the norm
questions.answer: an irregularity or deviation from the norm
questions.explanation: An 'anomaly' is something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected, as is the case with a statistical result that is unlike all others.

questions.question: He took a second job in the evenings to **augment** his income and save for a new car. What does 'augment' mean?
questions.explanation: To 'augment' income means to add to it or increase it, which is the purpose of taking a second job.

questions.question: The clear sky and perfect weather on the morning of their wedding felt like an **auspicious** start to their new life together. What does 'auspicious' mean?
questions.explanation: An 'auspicious' event is one that suggests a positive and successful future, as the clear weather seemed to promise a good future for the wedding.

questions.question: The university's new report on climate change is considered the most **authoritative** source on the subject, widely cited by other researchers. What does 'authoritative' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Authoritative' refers to a source that is seen as reliable and trustworthy because of its expertise and command of the subject.

questions.question: The remote tribe fought for **autonomy**, seeking the right to govern themselves without interference from the central government. What does 'autonomy' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Autonomy' is the right or condition of self-government, which is what the tribe was fighting for against the central government.

questions.question: The doctor assured me that the lump was **benign** and not a cause for concern. What does 'benign' mean?
questions.explanation: In a medical context, a 'benign' growth is one that is not harmful or cancerous, meaning it is not a threat.

questions.question: His **blatant** disrespect for the rules was obvious to everyone; he broke them without any attempt to hide his actions. What does 'blatant' mean?
questions.explanation: Blatant describes an action that is done in an open and unashamed way, so it is obvious to all.

questions.question: Dealing with the city's **bureaucracy** can be frustrating due to the numerous forms and departments you have to go through to get a simple permit. What does 'bureaucracy' mean?
choices: a system of government with multiple departments
questions.answer: a system of government with multiple departments
questions.explanation: 'Bureaucracy' refers to a system of government or administration run by a complex network of departments and officials, often associated with a lot of paperwork and rules.

questions.question: The battlefield was a scene of pure **carnage** after the long and bloody battle. What does 'carnage' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Carnage' refers to the killing of a large number of people, as would be the result of a bloody battle.

questions.question: The historian's book is a detailed **chronicle** of the events leading up to the war, arranged in the order they happened. What is a 'chronicle'?
choices: a factual written account of events in historical order
questions.answer: a factual written account of events in historical order
questions.explanation: A 'chronicle' is a historical account of events arranged in chronological order, which accurately describes the historian's book.

questions.question: He was always **circumspect** with his investments, carefully considering all possible risks before making a decision. What does 'circumspect' mean?
questions.explanation: To be 'circumspect' means to be cautious and to look at all possible circumstances before acting, which is a good quality for an investor.

questions.question: She wrote the dialogue in her novel using **colloquial** language to make it sound more natural and realistic. What does 'colloquial' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Colloquial' refers to language used in ordinary or familiar conversation, which makes dialogue sound more realistic.

questions.question: The witness's story was so detailed and consistent with the evidence that the jury found him to be a **credible** source. What does 'credible' mean?
questions.explanation: A 'credible' source is one that can be believed, which is why the jury trusted the witness's story.

questions.question: The new fitness trend has gained a **cult** following, with people obsessively devoted to the workout routine. What does 'cult' mean?
choices: an obsessive devotion to a person or idea
a group that meets once a week
questions.answer: an obsessive devotion to a person or idea
questions.explanation: A 'cult' following is a group of people who show an excessive or obsessive devotion to a particular trend, person, or idea.

questions.question: In **deference** to his many years of experience, the younger members of the team allowed the senior partner to lead the meeting. What does 'deference' mean?
choices: a feeling of anger or frustration
questions.explanation: 'Deference' is a show of respect for a person's authority or status, which is why the younger members yielded to the senior partner.

questions.question: There is a strong **dichotomy** in the country's politics, with the population deeply divided into two opposing political parties. What does 'dichotomy' mean?
choices: a division or contrast between two things
questions.answer: a division or contrast between two things
questions.explanation: 'Dichotomy' refers to a split into two opposing parts, which accurately describes the division in the country's politics.

questions.question: Please do not **disparage** my efforts; even if you think they are not good enough, I am still trying my best. What does 'disparage' mean?
questions.explanation: To 'disparage' means to regard or represent as being of little worth, which is what the speaker is asking the other person not to do to their efforts.

questions.question: The economic **disparity** between the rich and the poor has grown significantly in recent years. What does 'disparity' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Disparity' refers to a great difference, as in the unequal distribution of wealth between the rich and the poor.

questions.question: The organization's goal is to **disseminate** information about the disease to as many people as possible. What does 'disseminate' mean?
choices: to reduce the amount of information
to gather information from a few sources
questions.explanation: To 'disseminate' means to spread something, especially information, widely among people.

questions.question: The government arrested a **dissident** who was openly speaking out against the new regime. A 'dissident' is someone who:
choices: disagrees with an established political system
questions.answer: disagrees with an established political system
questions.explanation: A 'dissident' is a person who opposes official policy, especially that of an authoritarian state.

questions.question: The teacher tried to **elicit** a response from the shy student by asking a series of simple questions. What does 'elicit' mean?
choices: to draw forth or provoke a response
to suppress or hide a reaction
questions.answer: to draw forth or provoke a response
questions.explanation: To 'elicit' means to draw out or evoke a reaction or response from someone, as the teacher was trying to get the student to speak.

questions.question: The disappearance of the ancient civilization remains an **enigma** to historians, as no one can figure out what happened to them. What does 'enigma' mean?
questions.explanation: An 'enigma' is something that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand, which fits the description of a historical event that cannot be explained.

questions.question: A butterfly's life is **ephemeral**, lasting only a few weeks before it passes. What does 'ephemeral' mean?
choices: lasting for a very short time
lasting for a very long time
questions.answer: lasting for a very short time
questions.explanation: 'Ephemeral' describes something that is short-lived, as is the case with a butterfly's life cycle.

questions.question: The statue was built to pay **homage** to the soldiers who fought bravely in the war. What does 'homage' mean?
choices: to doubt the worth of something
questions.explanation: To 'pay homage' means to show honor or respect, which is a common purpose for building a monument.

questions.question: The team's defeat was **ignominious**; they not only lost the game but were also widely ridiculed for their poor performance. What does 'ignominious' mean?
choices: deserving of public shame or disgrace
questions.answer: deserving of public shame or disgrace
questions.explanation: 'Ignominious' describes an event or action that brings public disgrace or shame, which is how the team's defeat was perceived.

questions.question: He was arrested for selling **illicit** goods, as the items were forbidden by law. What does 'illicit' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Illicit' refers to something forbidden by law, rule, or custom, which is why the person was arrested for selling the goods.

questions.question: The laws of physics are **immutable**; they cannot be changed by human wishes or actions. What does 'immutable' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Immutable' describes something that is not capable of or susceptible to change, which is a core characteristic of the laws of physics.

questions.question: The negotiations reached an **impasse** when neither side was willing to compromise, and the talks broke down. What is an 'impasse'?
choices: a situation where no progress is possible
the very beginning of a project
questions.answer: a situation where no progress is possible
questions.explanation: An 'impasse' is a situation in which no progress is possible, as was the case when the negotiations stopped due to a lack of compromise.

questions.question: Although the manager never said it directly, the request for overtime was **implicit** in his email about the project deadline. What does 'implicit' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Implicit' means something that is suggested but not stated directly, which is why the request for overtime was understood without being explicitly said.

questions.question: The city's soup kitchen provides meals for the **indigent** and homeless population. An 'indigent' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Indigent' describes a person who is very poor, needy, or impoverished, which is why they would be a recipient of aid from a soup kitchen.

questions.question: During the summer vacation, he became very **indolent**, spending all his days lying on the couch and watching television. What does 'indolent' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Indolent' means lazy or having a disposition to avoid exertion, which describes his summer behavior.

questions.question: The **ingenuous** young boy believed everything the traveling salesman told him without a second thought. An 'ingenuous' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Ingenuous' means innocent, naive, and trusting, which is why the boy believed the salesman so easily.

questions.question: Every person has an **inherent** right to freedom and justice that cannot be taken away. What does 'inherent' mean?
choices: existing as a natural, essential part
questions.answer: existing as a natural, essential part
questions.explanation: 'Inherent' means an essential or permanent characteristic that is a natural part of something or someone.

questions.question: The disease was **insidious**, spreading slowly and without symptoms for years before it was finally diagnosed. What does 'insidious' mean?
choices: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects
questions.answer: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects
questions.explanation: 'Insidious' refers to something that works in a subtle or sneaky way with a harmful outcome, which describes how the disease spread.

questions.question: The company was declared **insolvent** after it was no longer able to pay its debts. What does 'insolvent' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Insolvent' is the state of being unable to pay debts owed, which is why the company was declared bankrupt.

questions.question: The professor's lecture felt **interminable**, as it went on for three hours without a break. What does 'interminable' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Interminable' is a word used to describe something that seems to be without end, which is how the long lecture felt.

questions.question: The **intrepid** explorer was the first person to cross the continent's most dangerous desert. An 'intrepid' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Intrepid' is an adjective used to describe someone who is fearless and adventurous in the face of danger.

questions.question: The value of art is **intrinsic**; its worth is not in its price but in its beauty and meaning. What does 'intrinsic' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Intrinsic' means belonging naturally or being essential to something's nature, which is how the beauty and meaning relate to the art.

questions.question: The doctor's explanation was full of medical **jargon** that was difficult for the patient to understand. What is 'jargon'?
choices: specialized language used by a group or profession
a story told in a specific way
questions.answer: specialized language used by a group or profession
questions.explanation: 'Jargon' is a specialized vocabulary specific to a particular field or group, making it difficult for outsiders to understand.

questions.question: Dogs have a **keen** sense of smell that allows them to track scents for miles. What does 'keen' mean?
questions.explanation: A 'keen' sense describes one that is sharp, sensitive, or highly developed, as is the case with a dog's sense of smell.

questions.question: She had a **latent** talent for painting that she only discovered in her sixties, after she retired. What does 'latent' mean?
choices: existing but not yet developed or apparent
questions.answer: existing but not yet developed or apparent
questions.explanation: 'Latent' describes a quality or ability that is present but not yet active or developed, which fits the description of her newfound talent.

questions.question: He felt **lethargic** all day after staying up late the night before and had no energy to do his homework. What does 'lethargic' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Lethargic' means feeling a lack of energy or enthusiasm, which is a common effect of not getting enough sleep.

questions.question: His explanation of the complex theory was so **lucid** that even I, with no prior knowledge, could understand it. What does 'lucid' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Lucid' means expressed clearly or easy to understand, which is why the explanation made sense to someone with no background in the subject.

questions.question: After winning the competition, the champion was **magnanimous** in victory, shaking his opponent's hand and praising his efforts. What does 'magnanimous' mean?
choices: generous and forgiving toward a rival
questions.answer: generous and forgiving toward a rival
questions.explanation: 'Magnanimous' describes a person who is generous, forgiving, or noble, especially toward a rival or competitor.

questions.question: The villain's **malevolent** plan to steal the city's water supply was meant to cause great harm to the population. A 'malevolent' person or thing is:
choices: wishing to do evil or cause harm to others
questions.answer: wishing to do evil or cause harm to others
questions.explanation: 'Malevolent' describes something that is evil or harmful in its intent, as was the villain's plan.

questions.question: The Central Bank is responsible for creating **monetary** policy to manage the country's money supply and interest rates. 'Monetary' relates to:
questions.explanation: 'Monetary' is an adjective that relates to money or currency, which is the focus of the Central Bank's policy.

questions.question: The forest was home to a **myriad** of different species of plants and animals. What does 'myriad' mean?
choices: a countless or extremely great number
questions.answer: a countless or extremely great number
questions.explanation: 'Myriad' is a word used to describe a very large or indefinite number of things, which fits the diversity of the forest.

questions.question: The suspect gave a **nebulous** description of the crime, making it difficult for the police to understand what happened. What does 'nebulous' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Nebulous' is an adjective used to describe something that is vague, hazy, or unclear, which is why the police could not understand the description.

questions.question: The meaning of the poem was **obscure** to most readers; it was hard to understand due to its complex symbolism. What does 'obscure' mean?
choices: not discovered or known about; uncertain
questions.answer: not discovered or known about; uncertain
questions.explanation: 'Obscure' means not discovered, known about, or understood, which is why the poem's meaning was difficult to grasp.

questions.question: Technological **obsolescence** is a constant problem for consumers, as new phones and computers are released every year. 'Obsolescence' refers to:
choices: the process of becoming more modern
questions.explanation: 'Obsolescence' is the process of something becoming obsolete or no longer useful, which is a common issue with rapidly changing technology.

questions.question: The ballroom was so **ornate** that every surface, from the ceiling to the walls, was covered in intricate carvings and gold leaf. What does 'ornate' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Ornate' describes something that is highly and often excessively decorated with complex patterns or details, which fits the description of the intricate carvings and gold leaf.

questions.question: After he broke the unwritten rule of their social group, his friends began to **ostracize** him, excluding him from all their plans. To 'ostracize' someone is to:
choices: exclude from a group or society
questions.answer: exclude from a group or society
questions.explanation: To 'ostracize' is to exclude someone from a social group or community, which is what the friends did to him by leaving him out of their plans.

questions.question: The meal was barely **palatable**; although it was edible, no one found it particularly tasty. A 'palatable' meal is:
questions.explanation: 'Palatable' describes something that is acceptable or pleasant to the taste, which the meal was not, despite being edible.

questions.question: When the verdict was announced, a **palpable** tension filled the courtroom, as you could feel the anxious energy in the air. What does 'palpable' mean?
choices: so intense as to be almost felt physically
questions.answer: so intense as to be almost felt physically
questions.explanation: 'Palpable' describes a feeling or atmosphere that is so intense that it seems tangible, as if you could touch it.

questions.question: Many people hope that science will discover a **panacea**—a single cure for all diseases. What is a 'panacea'?
choices: a remedy for all ills or difficulties
a type of illness or disease
a temporary fix for a single problem
questions.answer: a remedy for all ills or difficulties
questions.explanation: A 'panacea' is a solution or remedy for all problems or diseases, which is the universal cure scientists are hoping to find.

questions.question: The invention of the internet created a new **paradigm** for how we communicate and access information. What is a 'paradigm'?
choices: a typical example or model of something
questions.answer: a typical example or model of something
questions.explanation: A 'paradigm' is a typical pattern or model, representing a fundamental way of thinking or doing things, which the internet's invention changed.

questions.question: It's a strange **paradox** that spending money on expensive clothes for a party can make you feel both richer and poorer at the same time. What is a 'paradox'?
choices: a statement that seems self-contradictory but is true
a statement that is clearly false
questions.answer: a statement that seems self-contradictory but is true
questions.explanation: A 'paradox' is a statement that appears to contradict itself but contains a deeper truth, as in the case of feeling both rich and poor.

questions.question: The city's **perennial** traffic problems seem to get worse every single year. What does 'perennial' mean?
choices: lasting or existing for a long or indefinite time
questions.answer: lasting or existing for a long or indefinite time
questions.explanation: 'Perennial' describes something that continues to exist or recur over a long period, which fits the ongoing traffic problems.

questions.question: She preferred to stay on the **periphery** of the main group, only listening to their conversations from a distance. What does 'periphery' mean?
choices: the outer limits or edge of an area or group
the very beginning of an event
the hidden inside of a place
questions.answer: the outer limits or edge of an area or group
questions.explanation: The 'periphery' is the outer edge of an area, which in this case refers to her staying on the edge of the social group.

questions.question: The **placid** lake was so calm that its surface perfectly reflected the mountains and sky. What does 'placid' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Placid' is an adjective used to describe a person or a body of water that is calm, serene, and not easily disturbed.

questions.question: In the courtroom, the **plaintiff** presented his case, arguing that the company had caused him personal injury. The 'plaintiff' is:
choices: the person who brings a legal case against another
the person who is on trial
the lawyer who defends the accused
the judge who makes the final ruling
questions.answer: the person who brings a legal case against another
questions.explanation: A 'plaintiff' is the person who initiates a lawsuit or brings a legal action against another party.

questions.question: The film's ending was so **poignant** that it left the entire audience in tears. What does 'poignant' mean?
choices: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret
questions.answer: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret
questions.explanation: 'Poignant' describes something that deeply touches or moves the emotions, often with a feeling of sadness or nostalgia.

questions.question: The medicine was so **potent** that it relieved his pain almost immediately. What does 'potent' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Potent' describes something that has a very strong effect, which in this case refers to the medicine's ability to relieve pain quickly.

questions.question: The hikers found themselves in a **precarious** situation, clinging to a narrow ledge with a long drop below them. A 'precarious' situation is:
choices: not securely held in place; dangerous
questions.answer: not securely held in place; dangerous
questions.explanation: 'Precarious' means not securely in place and therefore likely to fall or collapse, which perfectly describes the dangerous situation of the hikers.

questions.question: The new safety regulations will **preclude** any further accidents from happening on the factory floor. To 'preclude' something means to:
questions.explanation: To 'preclude' is to make something impossible by taking prior action, which is the goal of the new safety regulations.

questions.question: The invention of the steam engine was a **precursor** to the Industrial Revolution. What is a 'precursor'?
choices: something that comes before and signals the approach of another
the final outcome of an event
questions.answer: something that comes before and signals the approach of another
questions.explanation: A 'precursor' is something that precedes and indicates the existence or development of something else, as the steam engine came before the Industrial Revolution.

questions.question: He was a **prodigal** son who quickly spent his entire inheritance on extravagant parties and luxury items. A 'prodigal' lifestyle is:
choices: characterized by wasteful and reckless spending
questions.answer: characterized by wasteful and reckless spending
questions.explanation: 'Prodigal' describes a person who spends money or resources recklessly and wastefully, which fits the son's behavior.

questions.question: The new skyscraper was a **prodigious** feat of engineering, stretching hundreds of feet into the sky. What does 'prodigious' mean?
choices: remarkably or impressively great in size or extent
questions.answer: remarkably or impressively great in size or extent
questions.explanation: 'Prodigious' is used to describe something that is of a very great size, extent, or degree, as is the case with a massive skyscraper.

questions.question: When he was rescued from the fire, he offered **profuse** thanks to the firefighters for saving his life. What does 'profuse' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Profuse' means offered in great quantity or abundance, which describes the sincere and plentiful thanks he gave.

questions.question: A **prolific** author like Stephen King publishes several books every year. What does 'prolific' mean?
choices: producing a large amount of work or results
questions.answer: producing a large amount of work or results
questions.explanation: 'Prolific' describes someone who produces a large number of a particular type of work, such as a writer who publishes many books.

questions.question: He had a natural **propensity** for getting into trouble, which seemed to follow him wherever he went. What does 'propensity' mean?
choices: a natural tendency or inclination to behave a certain way
questions.answer: a natural tendency or inclination to behave a certain way
questions.explanation: A 'propensity' is a natural inclination or a deep-seated tendency to do something, which explains his repeated trouble.

questions.question: The house was ideal because of its close **proximity** to the school and the park. 'Proximity' means:
choices: a state of being completely separate
questions.explanation: 'Proximity' refers to the state of being close to someone or something, which is why the house's location was so desirable.

questions.question: The **pugnacious** young man was always looking for an argument and was quick to pick a fight with anyone who disagreed with him. A 'pugnacious' person is:
choices: eager or quick to argue or fight
questions.answer: eager or quick to argue or fight
questions.explanation: 'Pugnacious' is an adjective used to describe someone who is eager to fight or argue, which fits the description of the young man.

questions.question: The smell of vinegar has a **pungent** odor that can make your eyes water. A 'pungent' smell is:
choices: having a sharply strong smell or taste
questions.answer: having a sharply strong smell or taste
questions.explanation: 'Pungent' describes a sharp, intense quality, particularly in taste or smell, which is why vinegar can make your eyes water.

questions.question: The new laws were intentionally **punitive**, designed to severely punish repeat offenders. 'Punitive' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Punitive' describes something that is inflicted or intended as a punishment.

questions.question: He decided to **purge** his closet of all the old clothes he no longer wore. To 'purge' something means to:
choices: to cleanse or remove something undesirable
questions.answer: to cleanse or remove something undesirable
questions.explanation: To 'purge' means to get rid of or remove something from a place, which is what he was doing with his old clothes.

questions.question: She had some **qualms** about lying to her parents, but she went ahead with her plan anyway. 'Qualms' most nearly means:
choices: a feeling of uneasiness or doubt
questions.answer: a feeling of uneasiness or doubt
questions.explanation: 'Qualms' are feelings of doubt, worry, or uneasiness about whether an action is right, which is what she felt about lying.

questions.question: The police were called in to **quell** the rioting, as the crowd was growing more out of control. To 'quell' a riot means to:
choices: put an end to by force; suppress
questions.answer: put an end to by force; suppress
questions.explanation: To 'quell' means to put an end to something, typically a disturbance or rebellion, by using force or authority.

questions.question: The teacher had a difficult time with the **recalcitrant** student who refused to follow any of the classroom rules. A 'recalcitrant' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Recalcitrant' describes someone who is stubbornly defiant and disobedient, which fits the student who would not follow the rules.

questions.question: After his poor performance, the coach decided to **relegate** the player to the bench for the rest of the game. To 'relegate' someone is to:
choices: assign to a lower or less important position
questions.answer: assign to a lower or less important position
questions.explanation: To 'relegate' means to demote or send someone to a lower position or status, which is what the coach did by putting the player on the bench.

questions.question: She had to **relinquish** her control of the company when she retired and hand it over to her successor. To 'relinquish' power means to:
choices: voluntarily cease to keep or claim; to give up
questions.answer: voluntarily cease to keep or claim; to give up
questions.explanation: To 'relinquish' means to voluntarily give up or surrender something, such as power or control.

questions.question: A former soldier turned **renegade**, he now fights against the very government he once served. A 'renegade' is a:
choices: a person who betrays an organization; a rebel
questions.answer: a person who betrays an organization; a rebel
questions.explanation: A 'renegade' is a person who deserts or betrays an organization, country, or cause, which fits the soldier's new role.

questions.question: The politician's speech was meant to **repudiate** the rumors that he was involved in the scandal. To 'repudiate' an idea is to:
choices: refuse to accept or be associated with
questions.answer: refuse to accept or be associated with
questions.explanation: To 'repudiate' means to reject or refuse to acknowledge something, such as the politician's rejection of the rumors.

questions.question: A bachelor's degree is a **requisite** for this job, so you cannot be considered without one. A 'requisite' skill is:
questions.explanation: 'Requisite' describes something that is required or necessary for a particular purpose or position.

questions.question: After the public outcry, the city council decided to **rescind** the unpopular new law. To 'rescind' a law means to:
questions.explanation: To 'rescind' means to officially cancel or repeal a law, agreement, or decision.

questions.question: The army general was **resolute** in his decision and would not be swayed from his course of action. A 'resolute' leader is:
choices: a person who often changes their mind
questions.explanation: 'Resolute' describes a person who is firmly determined and unwavering in their purpose.

questions.question: After working for twelve hours straight, the construction crew was given a short **respite** to rest and eat lunch. A 'respite' is:
choices: a short period of rest or relief
questions.answer: a short period of rest or relief
questions.explanation: A 'respite' is a brief interval of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant.

questions.question: The critic’s review was a **scathing** attack on the film, tearing apart every aspect of it from the acting to the plot. A 'scathing' remark is:
questions.explanation: 'Scathing' describes a remark or a review that is severely critical and hurtful.

questions.question: The accountant was so **scrupulous** that he double-checked every number to ensure there were no errors. A 'scrupulous' worker is:
choices: diligent, thorough, and attentive to detail
questions.answer: diligent, thorough, and attentive to detail
questions.explanation: 'Scrupulous' describes a person who is very careful and conscientious, paying great attention to detail and acting with integrity.

questions.question: The new laws were designed to be completely **secular**, having no connection to any particular religion. 'Secular' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Secular' is an adjective used to describe something that is not connected with religious or spiritual matters.

questions.question: The vet had to **sedate** the nervous dog before he could safely treat its injury. To 'sedate' a patient is to:
choices: calm or make them sleepy with a drug
questions.answer: calm or make them sleepy with a drug
questions.explanation: To 'sedate' a person or animal is to administer a drug to calm them or make them feel sleepy and tranquil.

questions.question: He developed a **sedentary** lifestyle after he started working a desk job, spending most of his day sitting. A 'sedentary' lifestyle is:
choices: involving little to no physical activity
questions.answer: involving little to no physical activity
questions.explanation: 'Sedentary' is an adjective used to describe a lifestyle or occupation that involves a great deal of sitting and not much physical activity.

questions.question: Due to the storm, power outages were **sporadic** throughout the city, happening in some neighborhoods but not others. 'Sporadic' most nearly means:
choices: occurring at irregular intervals or places
questions.answer: occurring at irregular intervals or places
questions.explanation: 'Sporadic' describes an event that occurs irregularly or randomly, as the power outages did throughout the city.

questions.question: A **stalwart** supporter of the team, she attended every single game for over two decades. A 'stalwart' supporter is:
questions.explanation: 'Stalwart' describes a person who is very loyal and dedicated to a cause or organization.

questions.question: The university has **stringent** admission requirements, which makes it very difficult for most students to get in. What does 'stringent' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Stringent' describes rules or requirements that are strict, precise, and demanding.

questions.question: After taking the medication, he was in a drowsy **stupor** and could not think clearly. A 'stupor' is a state of:
questions.explanation: A 'stupor' is a state of near unconsciousness, in which a person is dazed and unable to think or feel properly.

questions.question: She gave a **succinct** report, summarizing all the key findings in just a few sentences. A 'succinct' speech is:
questions.explanation: 'Succinct' means expressed in a concise and clear manner, which fits the description of a report that summarizes key findings briefly.

questions.question: The forecast called for a **sultry** afternoon, with high temperatures and high humidity that made the air feel heavy. What is 'sultry' weather?
questions.explanation: 'Sultry' is a term used to describe weather that is hot and humid, causing a sense of oppressive heat.

questions.question: Discussing money and salaries is often considered a social **taboo** in many cultures. Something that is 'taboo' is:
choices: a practice forbidden by social or cultural custom
a topic that is encouraged and common
a subject that is widely discussed
something that is allowed for everyone
questions.answer: a practice forbidden by social or cultural custom
questions.explanation: A 'taboo' is a social or cultural custom that prohibits or forbids a particular action or topic.

questions.question: Known for being **taciturn**, he rarely spoke during meetings and only answered with a nod or a single word. A 'taciturn' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Taciturn' describes a person who is habitually reserved and does not say much.

questions.question: Rumors about the scandal were **rampant**, spreading quickly and uncontrollably throughout the town. What does 'rampant' mean?
choices: spreading unchecked or out of control
questions.answer: spreading unchecked or out of control
questions.explanation: 'Rampant' is an adjective used to describe something that is growing or spreading without any control.

questions.question: The **tenacious** student would not give up, even after failing the test five times. A 'tenacious' student is:
choices: a person who gives up easily
questions.explanation: 'Tenacious' describes someone who is determined and persistent, holding on firmly to a goal.

questions.question: The manager's **terse** reply to my question was simply 'no,' leaving me with no further information. A 'terse' reply is:
questions.explanation: 'Terse' describes a statement or reply that is brief and abrupt, often to the point of being rude.

questions.question: The hero's last-minute actions managed to **thwart** the villain's evil plan. To 'thwart' a plan means to:
choices: successfully prevent from accomplishing a goal
help to start a new plan
questions.answer: successfully prevent from accomplishing a goal
questions.explanation: To 'thwart' is to prevent someone from accomplishing something or to oppose and defeat their plans.

questions.question: After the team lost the championship, the coach launched into a furious **tirade** at the players. A 'tirade' is:
choices: a long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
questions.answer: a long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
questions.explanation: A 'tirade' is a prolonged outburst of angry and bitter verbal criticism.

questions.question: The artist's work is considered to **transcend** the normal limits of human creativity. To 'transcend' limits means to:
choices: go beyond or rise above a boundary
questions.answer: go beyond or rise above a boundary
questions.explanation: To 'transcend' means to go beyond the range or limits of something, which is what the artist's work did.

questions.question: The city has a large **transient** population of students who only live there during the school year. A 'transient' visitor is:
choices: lasting only for a short time
a person who is a local citizen
questions.answer: lasting only for a short time
questions.explanation: 'Transient' describes something that is only temporary or lasting for a short time, like the students who only live there for a year.

questions.question: The movie was filled with **trite** phrases like 'you can do it!' that had been used in countless other films. A 'trite' phrase is:
questions.explanation: 'Trite' describes a remark or idea that is overused and therefore lacks originality or freshness.

questions.question: In today's world, cell phones are an **ubiquitous** technology; they are found just about everywhere you go. 'Ubiquitous' means:
questions.explanation: 'Ubiquitous' is an adjective that describes something that is present everywhere, which fits the widespread use of cell phones.

questions.question: The prosecution’s argument was **untenable** because it was based on a witness who had been proven to be lying. An 'untenable' argument is:
choices: not able to be supported or defended
questions.answer: not able to be supported or defended
questions.explanation: 'Untenable' describes a position or argument that cannot be defended against criticism or attack.

questions.question: The diplomat was known for his **urbane** and polished manners, making him a charming and sophisticated host. An 'urbane' gentleman is:
questions.explanation: 'Urbane' is an adjective used to describe a person who is courteous and refined in manner, fitting the description of a sophisticated host.

questions.question: The new research findings helped to **validate** the scientist's original hypothesis. To 'validate' a claim is to:
choices: confirm or prove it to be true
questions.answer: confirm or prove it to be true
questions.explanation: To 'validate' is to confirm that something is true or accurate, which is what the new research did for the scientist's hypothesis.

questions.question: The small company was considered the **vanguard** of a new technological movement, leading the way for others to follow. The 'vanguard' of a movement is:
choices: the leading part of a group or movement
the last part of a group
the middle section of a group
questions.answer: the leading part of a group or movement
questions.explanation: The 'vanguard' is the leading position in a group or a movement, which the company held in the new technological field.

questions.question: The candidate made a **vehement** speech against the new policy, using strong and passionate language to express his disapproval. A 'vehement' protest is:
choices: showing intense feeling or strong emotion
questions.answer: showing intense feeling or strong emotion
questions.explanation: 'Vehement' describes something that is done with strong, intense, and often angry feeling, which fits the tone of the candidate's speech.

questions.question: The student’s **verbose** essay was filled with unnecessary descriptions, making it difficult to find the main point. A 'verbose' essay is:
choices: using or containing more words than needed
questions.answer: using or containing more words than needed
questions.explanation: 'Verbose' means using too many words, which is why the essay was difficult to read and lacked a clear main point.

questions.question: Climbing the tall ladder gave him a sense of **vertigo**, and he felt as if the world were spinning around him. People with 'vertigo' feel:
choices: a sensation of whirling and loss of balance
questions.answer: a sensation of whirling and loss of balance
questions.explanation: 'Vertigo' is a specific medical condition that causes a sensation of spinning or dizziness, which is why he felt the world was spinning.

questions.question: The ancient stone foundation was the only **vestige** of the old castle that once stood on the hill. A 'vestige' of an old castle is:
choices: a small trace or remnant of something that once existed
questions.answer: a small trace or remnant of something that once existed
questions.explanation: A 'vestige' is a small remaining part of something larger or older, which is what the stone foundation was to the castle.

questions.question: He got **vicarious** enjoyment from watching his children play sports, feeling their excitement as if it were his own. This means he experienced excitement:
choices: in a boring and uninspired way
in a completely unreal and fake way
questions.explanation: 'Vicarious' describes a feeling that is experienced through the actions or feelings of another person, which is what he did by watching his children play.

questions.question: The security guards maintained constant **vigilance**, keeping a careful watch to prevent any trouble. 'Vigilance' most nearly means:
choices: the action of keeping careful watch
a state of sleepiness or drowsiness
questions.answer: the action of keeping careful watch
questions.explanation: 'Vigilance' is the state of keeping careful watch for possible danger or difficulty.

questions.question: The DNA evidence served to **vindicate** the man, finally clearing him of the crime he didn't commit. To 'vindicate' someone is to:
choices: clear someone of blame or suspicion
questions.answer: clear someone of blame or suspicion
questions.explanation: To 'vindicate' means to clear someone of blame or suspicion, as the DNA evidence did for the man.

questions.question: The doctors were worried about the **virulent** new strain of the flu, which was causing severe illness and hospitalizations. A 'virulent' disease is:
choices: extremely severe or harmful in its effects
questions.answer: extremely severe or harmful in its effects
questions.explanation: 'Virulent' describes a disease or a poison that is extremely severe, harmful, or deadly.

questions.question: The syrup was so **viscous** that it poured out of the bottle very slowly. A 'viscous' liquid is:
questions.explanation: 'Viscous' is an adjective used to describe a liquid that is thick and sticky, and thus resistant to flowing freely.

questions.question: Despite her age, the old woman had a great deal of **vitality**, hiking every day and volunteering in her community. 'Vitality' means:
choices: the state of being strong and active; energy
a sense of sadness or fatigue
a lack of energy or liveliness
questions.answer: the state of being strong and active; energy
questions.explanation: 'Vitality' refers to the state of being strong, full of energy, and lively.

questions.question: She was a **vivacious** hostess, full of energy and charm, and she made sure every guest felt welcome. A 'vivacious' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Vivacious' describes a person who is lively, animated, and full of energy.

questions.question: The political situation in the region was highly **volatile**, with the potential for sudden, violent changes at any moment. A 'volatile' situation is:
choices: likely to change rapidly and unpredictably
questions.answer: likely to change rapidly and unpredictably
questions.explanation: 'Volatile' describes a situation that is likely to change suddenly and often for the worse.

questions.question: He was a **voracious** reader, devouring an entire book in a single afternoon. A 'voracious' reader is:
choices: having a huge appetite or great eagerness
a person who reads very little
questions.answer: having a huge appetite or great eagerness
questions.explanation: 'Voracious' describes a strong, insatiable appetite for something, whether it be food or, in this case, books.

questions.question: The rock band reached the **zenith** of its popularity in the 1980s, when they sold out stadiums worldwide. The 'zenith' of a career is its:
choices: the time at which something is most powerful or successful
questions.answer: the time at which something is most powerful or successful
questions.explanation: 'Zenith' means the highest point or peak of something, which in this context refers to the peak of the band's popularity.

questions.question: She is the **epitome** of a modern leader, showing both strength and compassion. What does 'epitome' mean?
choices: a perfect or typical example of a quality
the complete opposite of a quality
a person who is hard to define
questions.answer: a perfect or typical example of a quality
questions.explanation: An 'epitome' is a person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type.

questions.question: Lying to your parents is not an **ethical** thing to do, even if it seems harmless. An 'ethical' decision follows:
choices: moral principles and accepted rules of conduct
questions.answer: moral principles and accepted rules of conduct
questions.explanation: 'Ethical' describes something that is morally right and follows a set of accepted principles of conduct.

questions.question: The restaurant serves a variety of **ethnic** dishes from different countries around the world. What does 'ethnic' relate to?
choices: a population subgroup with a common national or cultural tradition
questions.answer: a population subgroup with a common national or cultural tradition
questions.explanation: 'Ethnic' refers to the cultural or national traditions of a particular group of people.

questions.question: The lack of rain will only **exacerbate** the drought, making the problem even worse. To 'exacerbate' a problem is to:
choices: make it more severe or intense
questions.answer: make it more severe or intense
questions.explanation: To 'exacerbate' means to make a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling worse.

questions.question: The restaurant charged an **exorbitant** price for a single glass of water; it was far too expensive. 'Exorbitant' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Exorbitant' describes a price or amount that is unreasonably high.

questions.question: The report was well-written but contained a lot of **extraneous** details that had nothing to do with the main topic. 'Extraneous' most nearly means:
choices: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject
questions.answer: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject
questions.explanation: 'Extraneous' means not forming an essential or vital part of something, which describes the unnecessary details in the report.

questions.question: The speaker began to **falter** during his presentation, losing his confidence and stumbling over his words. If someone begins to 'falter', they:
choices: start to lose strength or momentum
questions.answer: start to lose strength or momentum
questions.explanation: To 'falter' means to lose strength, hesitation, or stumble, which fits the speaker's loss of confidence.

questions.question: The architect presented a new building plan that seemed **feasible** because it was practical and could be completed on time. A 'feasible' plan is:
choices: possible to do easily or conveniently
questions.answer: possible to do easily or conveniently
questions.explanation: 'Feasible' describes something that is possible to achieve or do, which is why the architect's plan was accepted.

questions.question: She was a **fervent** supporter of the charity, dedicating all her free time to its cause with great passion. 'Fervent' most nearly means:
choices: having or displaying a passionate intensity
questions.answer: having or displaying a passionate intensity
questions.explanation: 'Fervent' is an adjective used to describe a person who has intense and passionate feelings about something.

questions.question: He would often **flaunt** his expensive new car by driving it through the busiest streets to get attention. To 'flaunt' wealth is to:
choices: display it openly to provoke envy or admiration
questions.answer: display it openly to provoke envy or admiration
questions.explanation: To 'flaunt' means to display something ostentatiously, especially in order to show off.

questions.question: The **forensic** scientist presented her findings on the crime scene to the court. A 'forensic' report relates to:
choices: the use of scientific methods in the investigation of a crime
questions.answer: the use of scientific methods in the investigation of a crime
questions.explanation: 'Forensic' relates to the application of scientific knowledge to legal problems, especially in criminal investigations.

questions.question: He showed great **fortitude** during his long illness, enduring the pain with immense courage. 'Fortitude' most nearly means:
choices: courage in the face of pain or adversity
a feeling of fear or timidity
questions.answer: courage in the face of pain or adversity
questions.explanation: 'Fortitude' is the mental and emotional strength to endure pain or difficulty with courage.

questions.question: It was a **fortuitous** meeting that led to his dream job; he just happened to be in the right place at the right time. 'Fortuitous' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Fortuitous' describes an event that happens by chance, often resulting in a fortunate outcome.

questions.question: The **gregarious** new student made friends with everyone in his class almost immediately. A 'gregarious' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Gregarious' describes a person who is fond of company and sociable.

questions.question: The court described the act as a truly **heinous** crime due to its shocking and evil nature. A 'heinous' crime is:
questions.explanation: 'Heinous' describes a crime or act that is monstrously evil and shocking.

questions.question: The band announced they would be taking a two-year **hiatus** to rest and work on solo projects. Taking a 'hiatus' means:
choices: a pause or break in a sequence
working continuously and without a break
moving at a very fast pace
questions.answer: a pause or break in a sequence
questions.explanation: A 'hiatus' is a break or interruption in an activity or sequence, which is what the band did.

questions.question: The family was forced into a period of financial **austerity**, cutting all unnecessary expenses to save money. What does 'austerity' mean?
choices: strictness and severity of manner or living
a time of luxury and wealth
questions.answer: strictness and severity of manner or living
questions.explanation: 'Austerity' refers to a period of sternness or severity, especially in terms of self-discipline or financial cutbacks.

questions.question: The fire caused a complete **holocaust** in the forest, burning thousands of acres of trees to the ground. A 'holocaust' is:
choices: destruction or slaughter on a mass scale
questions.answer: destruction or slaughter on a mass scale
questions.explanation: A 'holocaust' refers to a great or complete destruction, especially by fire.

questions.question: The town had a very **homogeneous** population, made up almost entirely of people from the same cultural background. 'Homogeneous' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Homogeneous' describes something that is uniform or made up of the same kind of elements.

questions.question: He was such a **hypochondriac** that he was convinced he had a rare disease after reading a single article about it. A 'hypochondriac' often worries about:
choices: being excessively worried about one's health
questions.answer: being excessively worried about one's health
questions.explanation: A 'hypochondriac' is a person who is abnormally anxious about their health and imagines they have illnesses.

questions.question: The revolutionary painter was an **iconoclast**, challenging all the traditional art forms of his time. An 'iconoclast' is someone who:
questions.explanation: An 'iconoclast' is a person who attacks or criticizes established beliefs and institutions.

questions.question: The students gathered at the pub to **imbibe** some drinks after their final exams. To 'imbibe' means to:
questions.explanation: To 'imbibe' means to drink, especially alcohol.

questions.question: He was a famously **impecunious** artist who had to struggle to make a living. An 'impecunious' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Impecunious' describes a person who has very little money, which is why the artist struggled.

questions.question: The boy was scolded for his **impertinent** behavior when he interrupted the adult's conversation. 'Impertinent' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Impertinent' describes a person or their actions as not showing proper respect, being rude or insolent.

questions.question: Each time you click the button, the number increases by an **increment** of one. An 'increment' is:
questions.explanation: An 'increment' is an increase or addition, especially one of a series of fixed increases.

questions.question: Historically, the term **infidel** was used by a group to describe anyone who did not share their religious beliefs. An 'infidel' is:
choices: a person who does not believe in a particular religion
questions.answer: a person who does not believe in a particular religion
questions.explanation: An 'infidel' is a person who does not believe in religion or who adheres to a religion other than one's own.

questions.question: The judge issued an **injunction** to prevent the company from demolishing the historic building. An 'injunction' is:
choices: a formal court order to do or stop an action
questions.answer: a formal court order to do or stop an action
questions.explanation: An 'injunction' is a legal order from a court that prohibits a person or group from doing a specific act.

questions.question: After drinking too much coffee, she suffered from **insomnia** and was unable to sleep all night. If someone has 'insomnia', they cannot:
questions.explanation: 'Insomnia' is a common sleep disorder that makes it difficult to fall or stay asleep.

questions.question: They were close friends who shared a deep sense of emotional **intimacy**. 'Intimacy' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Intimacy' refers to close familiarity, which is often a result of having a close relationship with someone.

questions.question: After the argument, the politician spewed a stream of angry **invective** at his opponent. 'Invective' most nearly means:
choices: insulting, abusive, or highly critical language
questions.answer: insulting, abusive, or highly critical language
questions.explanation: 'Invective' is an adjective that describes insulting, abusive, or highly critical language.

questions.question: The baby had **jaundice** shortly after birth, and his skin had a noticeable yellowish tint. If someone has 'jaundice', their skin may look:
questions.explanation: 'Jaundice' is a medical condition that causes the yellowing of the skin and eyes.

questions.question: His story about what happened didn't quite **jibe** with the evidence found at the scene. To 'jibe' with something means to:
choices: be in agreement or consistent with
disagree or be in opposition to
questions.answer: be in agreement or consistent with
questions.explanation: To 'jibe' means to be in harmony or in agreement, which the story was not with the evidence.

questions.question: As the concert began, the crowd started to **jostle** each other to get closer to the stage. In a crowd, people may 'jostle' you, meaning they:
questions.explanation: To 'jostle' means to push or bump against someone roughly, as people do in a crowded space.

questions.question: He had a natural **knack** for solving puzzles quickly and effortlessly. What is a 'knack'?
choices: a special skill or talent for doing something easily
questions.answer: a special skill or talent for doing something easily
questions.explanation: A 'knack' is a special skill, talent, or facility for doing something, which is why he was so good at puzzles.

questions.question: The old factory was left to **languish** after the company went out of business, falling into disrepair. To 'languish' means to:
choices: to lose or lack vitality; grow weak
questions.answer: to lose or lack vitality; grow weak
questions.explanation: To 'languish' means to lose strength or vitality and to suffer from being neglected.

questions.question: The new government plans to **levy** a tax on all luxury goods. Governments often 'levy' taxes, meaning they:
choices: impose or collect a tax or fee
lower the amount of a tax
questions.answer: impose or collect a tax or fee
questions.explanation: To 'levy' means to impose a tax, fee, or fine.

questions.question: As a writer, she had a vast **lexicon**, knowing the meaning of a great number of words. A 'lexicon' is:
choices: the vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge
questions.answer: the vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge
questions.explanation: A 'lexicon' refers to the vocabulary of a person or a language, which fits the description of the writer.

questions.question: The **loquacious** professor was known for his long, detailed lectures that rarely ended on time. A 'loquacious' person is:
choices: tending to talk a great deal; talkative
questions.answer: tending to talk a great deal; talkative
questions.explanation: 'Loquacious' is an adjective used to describe someone who talks a lot.

questions.question: His political opponent tried to **malign** his character by spreading false and hurtful rumors. To 'malign' someone means:
choices: to speak about them in a critical or malicious way
to respect their point of view
to stand in awe of them
questions.answer: to speak about them in a critical or malicious way
questions.explanation: To 'malign' means to speak ill of someone in a malicious and defamatory way.

questions.question: Her **melodramatic** reaction to a small scratch on her arm included loud crying and wailing. 'Melodramatic' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Melodramatic' describes behavior that is exaggeratedly emotional or sentimental, often for dramatic effect.

questions.question: He was given a **menial** job of cleaning the floors, which was seen as a low-level task. A 'menial' job is:
choices: not requiring much skill and lacking prestige
questions.answer: not requiring much skill and lacking prestige
questions.explanation: 'Menial' describes work that is not challenging and is generally seen as low-level or degrading.

questions.question: The team showed their true **mettle** by coming back from a huge deficit to win the game. 'Mettle' most nearly means:
choices: a person's ability to cope well with difficulties; spirit and resilience
a sense of fear or timidity
questions.answer: a person's ability to cope well with difficulties; spirit and resilience
questions.explanation: 'Mettle' refers to a person's courage, spirit, and strength of character.

questions.question: The actor's **narcissism** was on full display as he spent his entire interview talking about his own greatness. 'Narcissism' most nearly means:
choices: excessive interest in or admiration of oneself
a sense of kindness towards others
questions.answer: excessive interest in or admiration of oneself
questions.explanation: 'Narcissism' is an excessive interest in oneself and one's physical appearance.

questions.question: As a **neophyte** in the world of computer programming, she had a lot to learn. A 'neophyte' is:
choices: a person who is new to a subject or skill
questions.answer: a person who is new to a subject or skill
questions.explanation: A 'neophyte' is a person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief; a novice.

questions.question: The company's new policy was a **notable** change from their old ways. A 'notable' event is:
questions.explanation: 'Notable' describes something that is worthy of attention or remarkable because of its importance or excellence.

questions.question: The book explored topics related to the **occult**, such as magic and witchcraft. The word 'occult' relates to:
questions.explanation: 'Occult' refers to a mysterious or supernatural force or knowledge.

questions.question: The small country was ruled by an **oligarchy**, a small group of wealthy families who held all the power. An 'oligarchy' is government by:
questions.explanation: An 'oligarchy' is a form of government in which a small group of people holds all the power.

questions.question: In the story, the king believed he was **omnipotent**, able to control everything and everyone in his kingdom. 'Omnipotent' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Omnipotent' means having unlimited power, which is what the king believed he had.

questions.question: The mansion's **opulence** was shown by its gold-plated faucets, marble floors, and extravagant furniture. 'Opulence' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Opulence' refers to great wealth, extravagance, or luxury, which the mansion's features demonstrated.

questions.question: The teacher told the students a simple **parable** about a boy who cried wolf to teach them a lesson about honesty. A 'parable' is:
choices: a simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson
questions.answer: a simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson
questions.explanation: A 'parable' is a simple story used to teach a moral lesson.

questions.question: She was a **paragon** of kindness, known throughout the community for her generous spirit. 'Paragon' most nearly means:
choices: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a quality
questions.answer: a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a quality
questions.explanation: A 'paragon' is a model of excellence or perfection, which she was for kindness.

questions.question: The painting depicted a quiet, **pastoral** scene of a farmer tending his sheep in a green field. A 'pastoral' scene is:
choices: relating to the countryside and rural life
related to the city and urban areas
questions.answer: relating to the countryside and rural life
questions.explanation: 'Pastoral' is an adjective that describes something related to the countryside or rural life.

questions.question: As the oldest male in the family, he was considered the **patriarch**, making all the important decisions. A 'patriarch' is:
choices: the male head of a family or tribe
the female head of a family
a young child in a family
questions.answer: the male head of a family or tribe
questions.explanation: A 'patriarch' is the male head of a family or group.

questions.question: The sudden loud noise caused a great **perturbation** in the room, making everyone jump in surprise. 'Perturbation' most nearly means:
choices: a state of mental or emotional disturbance
questions.answer: a state of mental or emotional disturbance
questions.explanation: 'Perturbation' is a state of being agitated, disturbed, or worried.

questions.question: The wealthy **philanthropist** donated millions of dollars to build a new hospital for the city. A 'philanthropist' is someone who:
choices: seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially through generous donations
questions.answer: seeks to promote the welfare of others, especially through generous donations
questions.explanation: A 'philanthropist' is a person who promotes the welfare of others, especially by donating money to good causes.

questions.question: Even when faced with a crisis, he remained **phlegmatic**, staying calm and unemotional. A 'phlegmatic' person is:
choices: having a calm and unemotional temperament
questions.answer: having a calm and unemotional temperament
questions.explanation: 'Phlegmatic' describes a person who is not easily excited and remains calm and composed.

questions.question: Winning the Olympic gold medal was the **pinnacle** of her career as an athlete. Reaching the 'pinnacle' of success means:
choices: the highest point of a career or achievement
the very start of a career
questions.answer: the highest point of a career or achievement
questions.explanation: 'Pinnacle' refers to the most successful or highest point of something, such as a career.

questions.question: The cartoon character was a **portly** gentleman with a round belly and a good-natured smile. A 'portly' man is:
questions.explanation: 'Portly' is a polite term used to describe a person, usually a man, who is somewhat fat or stout.

questions.question: The dark clouds were a **prelude** to the storm that was about to hit the city. A 'prelude' is:
choices: an introduction to a more important event
the ending or conclusion of something
questions.answer: an introduction to a more important event
questions.explanation: A 'prelude' is an action or event that serves as an introduction to something more important.

questions.question: The police were determined to find the person who had **perpetrated** the crime. To 'perpetrate' a crime means to:
choices: carry out or commit a harmful action
hide the evidence of a crime
questions.answer: carry out or commit a harmful action
questions.explanation: To 'perpetrate' means to carry out or commit a harmful, illegal, or immoral act.

questions.question: The **rapacious** developer bought up all the land he could, showing no concern for the people who were displaced. A 'rapacious' person is:
questions.explanation: 'Rapacious' is an adjective used to describe a person who is aggressively greedy or hungry for money.

questions.question: Their friendship was built on a **reciprocal** relationship, where both people gave and received support. 'Reciprocal' most nearly means:
choices: given, felt, or done in return by both sides
questions.answer: given, felt, or done in return by both sides
questions.explanation: 'Reciprocal' describes a relationship where there is a mutual exchange between two or more people.

questions.question: The old man was a **recluse**, living alone in a cabin in the woods and avoiding all human contact. A 'recluse' is:
choices: a person who lives a solitary life and avoids people
questions.answer: a person who lives a solitary life and avoids people
questions.explanation: A 'recluse' is a person who lives in seclusion or isolation from others.

questions.question: The judge was known for his unshakeable **rectitude** and was praised for his moral integrity. 'Rectitude' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: 'Rectitude' refers to morally correct behavior or thinking.

questions.question: The plague was a terrible **scourge** on the population, causing immense suffering and death. A 'scourge' can refer to:
choices: a person or thing that causes great trouble or suffering
questions.answer: a person or thing that causes great trouble or suffering
questions.explanation: A 'scourge' is a person or thing that causes great trouble or suffering.

questions.question: The smell of fresh-baked cookies in the kitchen was meant to **tantalize** the children who were waiting to eat. To 'tantalize' someone is to:
choices: torment or tease with the sight of something desired
questions.answer: torment or tease with the sight of something desired
questions.explanation: To 'tantalize' is to torment someone by showing them something they desire but keeping it out of their reach.

questions.question: She had the **temerity** to ask the CEO for a raise on her very first day of work. 'Temerity' most nearly means:
choices: a feeling of fear or cowardice
questions.explanation: 'Temerity' is the quality of being recklessly bold or audacious.
